translated: Although the quality of darkness is also its cause, still, because of the predominance of passion alone in the occurrence of pain and activity, it is only that which is indicated.

original: etena sāttvikyā vṛttyā rajasi kṣīṇe so 'pi kṣīyata ity uktam /
analyzed: etena sāttvikyā vṛttyā rajasi kṣīṇe saḥ u pi kṣīyate iti uktam
translated: By this it is said that when passion is destroyed by the mode of goodness, that [darkness] is also destroyed.

original: athavā tasya katham anarthamārge pravartakatvam ity ata āha rajoguṇasya pravṛttyādilakṣaṇasya samudbhavo yasmāt /
analyzed: athavā tasya katham anartha mārge pravartaka tvam iti atas āha rajaḥ guṇasya pravṛtti ādi lakṣaṇasya samudbhavaḥ yasmāt
translated: Or, how is it that [passion] causes one to engage in the path of misfortune? Therefore it is said: because of the origin of the quality of passion, which is characterized by activity, etc.

original: kāmo hi viṣayābhilāṣātmakaḥ svayam udbhūto rajaḥ pravartayan puruṣaṃ duḥkhātmake karmaṇi pravartayati /
analyzed: kāmaḥ hi viṣaya abhilāṣa ātmakaḥ svayam udbhūtaḥ rajaḥ pravartayan puruṣam duḥkha ātmake karmaṇi pravartayati
translated: For desire, which consists of longing for objects, when arisen by itself, causing passion to act, causes the person to engage in action which has the nature of pain.

original: tenāyam avaśyaṃ hantavya ity abhiprāyaḥ /
analyzed: tena ayam avaśyam hantavyaḥ iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: The idea is that therefore it must certainly be killed.

original: nanu sāmadānabhedadaṇḍāś catvāra upāyās tatra prathamatrikasyāsambhave caturtho
analyzed: nanu sāma dāna bheda daṇḍāḥ catvāraḥ upāyāḥ tatra prathama trikasya asambhave
translated: But are not the four expedients of conciliation, bribery, dissension, and punishment, of which the first three are impossible, the fourth, punishment, to be employed?

original: daṇḍaḥ prayoktavyo na tu haṭhād evety āśaṅkya trayāṇām asambhavaṃ vaktuṃ viśinaṣṭi🔽mahāśano mahāpāpmeti /
analyzed: daṇḍaḥ prayoktavyaḥ na tu haṭhāt evā iti āśaṅkya trayāṇām asambhavam vaktum viśinaṣṭi  mahā aśanaḥ mahā pāpmā iti
translated: Not by force alone? Fearing this doubt, in order to state the impossibility of the three [first expedients], he specifies:🔽Of great appetite, of great impurity.

original: mahad aśanam asyeti mahāśanaḥ /
analyzed: mahat aśanam asya iti mahā aśanaḥ
translated: He is called of great appetite because he has great appetite.

original: yat pṛthivyāṃ vrīhiyavaṃ hiraṇyaṃ paśavaḥ striyaḥ /
analyzed: yat pṛthivyām vrīhi yavam hiraṇyam paśavaḥ striyaḥ
translated: Whatever rice, barley, gold, cattle, and women there are on the earth,

original: nālam ekasya tat sarvam iti matvā śamaṃ vrajet // iti smṛteḥ /
analyzed: na alam ekasya tat sarvam iti matvā śamam vrajet iti smṛteḥ
translated: Knowing that all that cannot be done by one alone, one should attain peace.

original: ato na dānena sandhātuṃ śakyaḥ /
analyzed: atas na dānena sandhātum śakyaḥ
translated: Therefore, he cannot be reconciled through gifts.

original: nāpi sāmabhedābhyāṃ yato mahāpāpmātyugraḥ /
analyzed: nā api sāma bhedābhyām yatas mahā pāpmā ati ugraḥ
translated: Nor through conciliation and dissension, because he is a very fierce great sinner.

original: tena hi balāt prerito 'niṣṭaphalam api jānan pāpaṃ karoti /
analyzed: tena hi balāt preritaḥ niṣṭa phalam api jānan pāpam karoti
translated: For, being impelled by him, one commits sin even knowing it to have undesirable consequences.

original: ato viddhi jānīhi enaṃ kāmam iha saṃsāre vairiṇam /
analyzed: atas viddhi jānīhi enam kāmam iha saṃsāre vairiṇam
translated: Therefore, know this desire to be an enemy in this world.

original: tad etat sarvaṃ vivṛtaṃ vārtikakāraiḥ ātmaivedam agra āsīt iti śrutivyākhyāne
analyzed: tat etat sarvam vivṛtam vārtika kāraiḥ ātmā eva idam agre āsīt iti śruti vyākhyāne
translated: All this has been explained by the commentators in the commentary on the Vedic text This very Self existed here in the beginning.

original: pravṛttau ca nivṛttau ca yathoktasyādhikāriṇaḥ /
analyzed: pravṛttau ca nivṛttau ca yathā uktasya adhikāriṇaḥ
translated: In the case of one who is qualified as stated, whether in engagement or disengagement,

original: svātantrye sati saṃsārasṛtau kasmāt pravartate //
analyzed: svātantrye sati saṃsāra sṛtau kasmāt pravartate
translated: when there is independence, why does he engage in the course of worldly existence?

original: na tu niḥśeṣavidhvastasaṃsārānarthavartmani /
analyzed: na tu niḥśeṣa vidhvasta saṃsāra anartha vartmani
translated: But not in the case of one whose path of worldly existence and misfortune has been completely destroyed,

original: nivṛttilakṣaṇe vācyaṃ kenāyaṃ preryate 'vaśaḥ //
analyzed: nivṛtti lakṣaṇe vācyam kena ayam preryate vaśaḥ
translated: in the case of one characterized by disengagement, it should be said by whom is he impelled helplessly?

original: anarthaparipākatvam api jānan pravartate /
analyzed: anartha paripāka tvam api jānan pravartate
translated: Even knowing the ripening of misfortune, one engages.

original: pāratantryam ṛte dṛṣṭā pravṛttir nedṛśī kvacit //
analyzed: pāratantryam ṛte dṛṣṭā pravṛttiḥ nā īdṛśī kvacid
translated: Without dependence, such engagement is not seen anywhere.

original: tasmāc chreyorthinaḥ puṃsaḥ prerako 'niṣṭakarmaṇi /
analyzed: tasmāt śreyaḥ arthinaḥ puṃsaḥ prerakaḥ niṣṭa karmaṇi
translated: Therefore, for a person seeking the highest good, the impeller in undesirable action,

original: vaktavyas tannirāsārtham ity arthā syāt parā śrutiḥ //🔽anāptapuruṣārtho 'yaṃ niḥśeṣānarthasaṅkulaḥ /
analyzed: vaktavyaḥ tad nirāsa artham iti arthā syāt parā śrutiḥ  an āpta puruṣa arthaḥ yam niḥśeṣa anartha saṅkulaḥ
translated: The other Vedic text would be for the purpose of refuting that, thus it would have a different meaning.🔽This one has not attained the human goal, is full of all kinds of harm.

original: ity akāmayatānāptān pumarthān sādhanair jaḍaḥ //
analyzed: iti a kāmayata an āptān pumarthān sādhanaiḥ jaḍaḥ
translated: Thus, the dull one, not desiring to attain the unattained human goals by the means,

original: jihāsati tathānarthān avidvān ātmani śritān /
analyzed: jihāsati tathā anarthān avidvān ātmani śritān
translated: Desires to abandon those harms residing in the self, being ignorant.

original: avidyodbhūtakāmaḥ sann atho khalv iti ca śrutiḥ //
analyzed: avidyā udbhūta kāmaḥ san atha u khalu iti ca śrutiḥ
translated: Being one whose desire has arisen from ignorance, the Vedic text says athā khalu.

original: akāmataḥ kriyāḥ kāścid dṛśyante neha kasyacit /🔽yad yad dhi kurute jantus tattatkāmasya ceṣṭitam //
analyzed: akāmataḥ kriyāḥ kāścid dṛśyante na iha kasyacid  yat yat hi kurute jantuḥ tat tat kāmasya ceṣṭitam
translated: Some actions are seen here of no one without desire.🔽Whatever a creature does, that is the activity of desire.

original: kāma eṣa krodha eṣa ity ādivacanaṃ smṛteḥ /
analyzed: kāmaḥ eṣa krodhaḥ eṣaḥ iti ādi vacanam smṛteḥ
translated: The statement beginning with this is desire, this is anger etc. is from the Smriti.

original: pravartako nāparo 'taḥ kāmād anyaḥ pratīyate // iti /
analyzed: pravartakaḥ kāmāt anyaḥ pratīyate iti
translated: Another instigator other than desire is not understood.

original: akāmata iti manuvacanam /
analyzed: akāmatas iti manuvacanam
translated: The statement of Manu is without desire.

original: anyat spaṣṭam ////
analyzed: anyat spaṣṭam
translated: The other is clear.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha.

original: eṣa kāma eva viṣayābhilāṣātmakaḥ puruṣaṃ pāpe pravartayati tenaiva prayuktaḥ puruṣaḥ pāpaṃ caratīty arthaḥ /
analyzed: eṣa kāmaḥ eva viṣaya abhilāṣa ātmakaḥ puruṣam pāpe pravartayati tena eva prayuktaḥ puruṣaḥ pāpam carati iti arthaḥ
translated: This desire itself, in the form of longing for objects, leads the person to sin. The meaning is that the person employed by that very [desire] commits sin.

original: eṣa kāma eva pṛthaktvena dṛśyamāna eṣa pratyakṣaḥ krodho bhavati /
analyzed: eṣa kāmaḥ eva pṛthaktvena dṛśyamānaḥ eṣa pratyakṣaḥ krodhaḥ bhavati
translated: This very desire, when seen separately, becomes this manifest anger.

original: kāma eva kenacit pratihato bhūtvā krodhākāreṇa pariṇamatīty arthaḥ /
analyzed: kāmaḥ eva kenacid pratihataḥ bhūtvā krodha ākāreṇa pariṇamati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: desire, being obstructed by someone, transforms into the form of anger.

original: kāmo rajoguṇasamudbhava iti rājasāt kāmād eva tāmasaḥ krodho jāyate ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: kāmaḥ rajaḥ guṇa samudbhavaḥ iti rājasāt kāmāt eva tāmasaḥ krodhaḥ jāyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: desire arises from the quality of rajas, and anger, which is born from tamas, arises from desire born of rajas.

original: kāmasya apekṣitapūraṇena nivṛttiḥ syād iti cen nety āha mahāśano mahad aśanaṃ yasya saḥ /
analyzed: kāmasya apekṣita pūraṇena nivṛttiḥ syāt iti ced na iti āha mahā aśanaḥ mahat aśanam yasya saḥ
translated: If it is argued that desire would cease by fulfilling what is desired, it is said that it is not so, that it has great appetite, that which has great eating.

original: yat pṛthivyāṃ vrīhiyavaṃ hiraṇyaṃ paśavaḥ striyaḥ /
analyzed: yat pṛthivyām vrīhi yavam hiraṇyam paśavaḥ striyaḥ
translated: What is on the earth, rice, barley, gold, cattle, women,

original: nālam ekasya tat sarvam iti matvā śamaṃ vrajet // iti smṛteḥ /
analyzed: na alam ekasya tat sarvam iti matvā śamam vrajet iti smṛteḥ
translated: it is not enough for one. Considering this, one should attain peace.

original: kāmasyāpekṣitaṃ pūrayitum aśakyam eva /
analyzed: kāmasya apekṣitam pūrayitum aśakyam eva
translated: Desire is indeed impossible to fulfill.

original: nanu dānena sandhātum aśakyaś cet sāmabhedābhyāṃ sa svavaśīkartavyaḥ /
analyzed: nanu dānena sandhātum aśakyaḥ ced sāma bhedābhyām sa sva vaśīkartavyaḥ
translated: If it is argued that if it cannot be appeased by giving, then it should be brought under one's control by conciliation and threats,

original: tatrāha mahāpāpmātyugraḥ ////
analyzed: tatra āha mahā pāpmā ati ugraḥ
translated: to that he says: It is a great sin, very fierce.🔽Balarama.

original: baladevaḥ / tatrāha bhagavān kāma iti /
analyzed: baladevaḥ tatra āha bhagavān kāmaḥ iti
translated: To that, the Blessed Lord says: Desire.

original: kāmaḥ prāktanavāsanāhetukaḥ śabdādiviṣayako 'bhilāṣaḥ puruṣaṃ pāpe prerayati tad anicchum api so 'sya preraka ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: kāmaḥ prāktana vāsanā hetukaḥ śabda ādi viṣayakaḥ bhilāṣaḥ puruṣam pāpe prerayati tat anicchum api saḥ sya prerakaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Desire, caused by past tendencies, is the longing for objects like sound, etc. It impels the person towards sin, even though he may not desire it. The meaning is that it is the impeller of this.

original: nanv abhicārādau krodho 'pi prerako dṛṣṭaḥ sa cendriyasyety ādaubhavatāpi pṛthag ukta iti cet / satyam /
analyzed: nanu abhicāra ādau krodhaḥ api prerakaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ sa ca indriyasya iti ādau bhavatā api pṛthak uktaḥ iti ced satyam
translated: But isn't anger also seen to be a motivator in black magic and such, and wasn't it mentioned separately in the verse beginning If that belongs to the sense faculty? True.

original: na sa tasmāt pṛthak /
analyzed: na sa tasmāt pṛthak
translated: But it is not separate from that.

original: kintv eṣa kāma eva kenacic cetanena pratihataḥ krodho bhavati /
analyzed: kintu eṣa kāmaḥ eva kenacid cetanena pratihataḥ krodhaḥ bhavati
translated: Rather, this anger is just desire obstructed by some conscious being.

original: dugdham ivāmlena yuktaṃ dadhi /
analyzed: dugdham iva amlena yuktam dadhi
translated: Like curd, which is milk combined with sourness.

original: kāmajaya eva krodhajaya iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: kāma jayaḥ eva krodha jayaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The point is that conquering anger is the same as conquering desire.

original: kīdṛśaḥ kāma ity āha rajoguṇeti /
analyzed: kīdṛśaḥ kāmaḥ iti āha rajaḥ guṇa iti
translated: What kind of desire is it? He says: that which is of the quality of rajas.

original: sattvavṛddhyā rajasi nirjite kāmo nirjitaḥ syād ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: sattva vṛddhyā rajasi nirjite kāmaḥ nirjitaḥ syāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that when rajas is conquered by the increase of sattva, desire would be conquered.

original: na cāpekṣitapradānena kāmasya nivṛttir ity āha mahāśana iti /
analyzed: na ca apekṣita pradānena kāmasya nivṛttiḥ iti āha mahā aśanaḥ iti
translated: And desire is not removed by giving what is expected, so he says: it has great appetite.

original: yat pṛthivyāṃ vrīhiyavaṃ hiraṇyaṃ paśavaḥ striyaḥ /
analyzed: yat pṛthivyām vrīhi yavam hiraṇyam paśavaḥ striyaḥ
translated: Whatever rice, barley, gold, cattle, and women there are on the earth,

original: nālam ekasya tat sarvam iti matvā śamaṃ vrajet //
analyzed: na alam ekasya tat sarvam iti matvā śamam vrajet
translated: that is not enough for one. Thinking this, one should attain peace.

original: iti smaraṇāt /
analyzed: iti smaraṇāt
translated: Thus it is remembered.

original: na ca sāmnā bhedena vā sa vaśībhaved ity āha mahāpāpmeti /
analyzed: na ca sāmnā bhedena vā sa vaśībhavet iti āha mahā pāpmā iti
translated: And he would not be mastered by conciliation or division, so he says: it is of great impurity.

original: yo 'tyugro vivekajñānavilopena niṣiddhe 'pi pravartayati tasmād iha dānayoge enaṃ
analyzed: viveka jñāna vilopena niṣiddhe pi pravartayati tasmāt iha dāna yoge enam
translated: From that very fierce [desire] which, by the destruction of the knowledge of discrimination, engages one even in what is prohibited, in this yoga of giving, one should conquer it.

original: vairiṇaṃ viddhi tathā ca jñānādibhis tribhir upāyaiḥ sandhātum aśakyatvād vakṣyamāṇena
analyzed: vairiṇam viddhi tathā ca jñāna ādibhiḥ tribhiḥ upāyaiḥ sandhātum aśakya tvāt vakṣyamāṇena
translated: And know the enemy to be like that, because it cannot be united with the three means such as knowledge, etc.

original: daṇḍena sa hantavya iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: daṇḍena sa hantavyaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And know the enemy to be like that, and because he cannot be reconciled by the three means such as knowledge, etc., the idea is that he should be killed by the means to be described.

original: īśvaraḥ karmāntaritaḥ parjanyavat sarvatra prerakaḥ /
analyzed: īśvaraḥ karma antaritaḥ parjanya vat sarvatra prerakaḥ
translated: The Lord, being separated by action, is the impeller everywhere like rain.

original: kāmas tu svayam eva pāpmāgre iti tathoktam ////🔽BhG /
analyzed: kāmaḥ tu svayam eva pāpmā agre iti tathā uktam  bhg
translated: But desire itself is sin in the beginning, hence it is said thus.🔽The Lord says that the enemy is desire:

original: dhūmenāvriyate vahnir yathādarśo malena ca /
analyzed: dhūmena āvriyate vahniḥ yathā ādarśaḥ malena ca
translated: As fire is covered by smoke, and a mirror by dirt,

original: yatholbenāvṛto garbhas tathā tenedam āvṛtam ////🔽śrīdharaḥ / kāmasya vairitvaṃ darśayati dhūmeneti /
analyzed: yathā ulbena āvṛtaḥ garbhaḥ tathā tena idam āvṛtam       darśayati   iti
translated: As an embryo is enclosed by the womb, so is this covered by that.

original: dhūmena sahajena yathā vahnir āvriyata ācchādyate /🔽yathā cādarśo malenāgantukena /
analyzed: dhūmena sahajena yathā vahniḥ āvriyate ācchādyate  yathā ca ādarśaḥ malena āgantukena
translated: The Lord shows that desire is an enemy: As fire is covered by smoke, which is born along with it,🔽As a mirror is covered by dirt, which is adventitious,

original: yathā colbena garbhaveṣṭanacarmaṇā garbhaḥ sarvato niruddha āvṛtaḥ /
analyzed: yathā ca ulbena garbhaveṣṭana carmaṇā garbhaḥ sarvatas niruddhaḥ āvṛtaḥ
translated: And as an embryo is completely obstructed and covered by the womb, by the skin that encloses the embryo,

original: tathāprakāratrayeṇāpi tena kāmenāvṛtam idam ////🔽madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: tathā prakāra trayeṇa api tena kāmena āvṛtam idam  madhusūdanaḥ
translated: So is this covered by that desire in three ways.

original: tasya mahāpāpmatvena vairtvam eva dṛṣṭāntaiḥ spaṣṭayati dhūmeneti /
analyzed: tasya mahā pāpma tvena vaiḥ tvam eva dṛṣṭāntaiḥ spaṣṭayati dhūmena iti
translated: The Lord clarifies that it is desire alone which is the enemy, since it is the greatest sin, by means of examples: As fire is covered by smoke, etc.

original: tatra śarīrārambhāt prāgantaḥkaraṇasthālabdhavṛttikatvāt sūkṣmaḥ kāmaḥ śarīrārambhakeṇa
analyzed: tatra śarīra ārambhāt prāk antaḥkaraṇa sthā labdha vṛttika tvāt sūkṣmaḥ kāmaḥ śarīra ārambhakeṇa
translated: There, prior to the beginning of the body, desire is subtle because it has not attained activity in the internal organ.

original: karmaṇā sthūlaśarīrāvacchinne labdhavṛttike 'ntaḥkaraṇe kṛtābhivyaktiḥ san sthūlo bhavati /
analyzed: karmaṇā sthūla śarīra avacchinne labdha vṛttike ntaḥkaraṇe kṛta abhivyaktiḥ san sthūlaḥ bhavati
translated: When manifested by the karma that begins the body in the internal organ that has attained activity in the limited gross body, it becomes gross.

original: sa eva viṣayasya cintyamānatāvasthāyāṃ punaḥ punar udricyamānaḥ sthūlataro bhavati /
analyzed: saḥ eva viṣayasya cintyamāna tā avasthāyām punar punar udricyamānaḥ sthūlataraḥ bhavati
translated: That same [desire], again and again increasing in the state of being contemplated on the object, becomes even grosser.

original: sa eva punar viṣayasya bhujyamānatāvasthāyām atyantodrekaṃ prāptaḥ sthūlatamo bhavati /
analyzed: saḥ eva punar viṣayasya bhujyamāna tā avasthāyām atyanta udrekam prāptaḥ sthūlatamaḥ bhavati
translated: That same [desire], again, in the state of being enjoyed on the object, having attained extreme intensity, becomes the grossest.

original: tatra prathamāvasthāyāṃ dṛṣṭāntaḥ yathā dhūmena sahajenāprakāśātmakena prakāśātmako vahnir āvriyate /
analyzed: tatra prathama avasthāyām dṛṣṭāntaḥ yathā dhūmena sahajena aprakāśa ātmakena prakāśa ātmakaḥ vahniḥ āvriyate
translated: There, the example in the first state is like fire, which is of the nature of light, being covered by smoke, which is of the nature of darkness and is co-existent.

original: dvitīyāvasthāyāṃ dṛṣṭāntaḥ yathādarśo malenāsahajenādarśotpattyanantaram udriktena /
analyzed: dvitīya avasthāyām dṛṣṭāntaḥ yathā ādarśaḥ malena asahajena ādarśa utpatti anantaram udriktena
translated: The example in the second state is like a mirror, which is of the nature of reflection, being covered by dirt, which is not co-existent with the mirror and increases after the mirror is produced.

original: cakāro 'vāntaravaidharmyasūcanārtha āvriyata iti kriyānukarṣaṇārthaś ca /
analyzed: cakāraḥ vā antara vaidharmya sūcana arthaḥ āvriyate iti kriyā anukarṣaṇa arthaḥ ca
translated: The word ca [in the text] is for indicating a minor difference and for drawing out the verb is covered.

original: tṛtīyāvasthāyāṃ
analyzed: tṛtīya avasthāyām
translated: In the third state,

original: dṛṣṭāntaḥ yatholbena jarāyuṇā garbhaveṣṭanacarmaṇātisthūlena sarvato nirudhyāvṛtas tathā prakāratrayeṇāpi tena kāmenedam āvṛtam /
analyzed: dṛṣṭāntaḥ yathā ulbena jarāyuṇā garbhaveṣṭana carmaṇā ati sthūlena sarvatas nirudhya āvṛtaḥ tathā prakāra trayeṇa api tena kāmena idam āvṛtam
translated: The example is: Just as a fetus is completely obstructed and covered by a very thick membrane, the womb-wrapping skin, so is this world covered by that desire in all three ways.

original: atra dhūmenāvṛto 'pi vahnir dāhādilakṣaṇaṃ svakāryaṃ karoti /
analyzed: atra dhūmena āvṛtaḥ vahniḥ dāha ādi lakṣaṇam sva kāryam karoti
translated: Here, even though fire is covered by smoke, it performs its own function characterized by burning, etc.

original: malenāvṛtas tv ādarśaḥ pratibimbagrahaṇalakṣaṇaṃ svakāryaṃ na karoti /
analyzed: malena āvṛtaḥ tu ādarśaḥ pratibimba grahaṇa lakṣaṇam sva kāryam na karoti
translated: But a mirror covered by dirt does not perform its own function characterized by reflecting images.

original: svacchatādharmamātratirodhānāt svarūpatas tūpalabhyata eva /
analyzed: svaccha tā dharma mātra tirodhānāt svarūpataḥ tu upalabhyate eva
translated: Because it merely obscures the property of clarity, but it is still perceived in its own form.

original: ulbenāvṛtas tu garbho na hastapādādiprasāraṇarūpaṃ svakāryaṃ karoti na vā svarūpata upalabhyata iti viśeṣaḥ ////
analyzed: ulbena āvṛtaḥ tu garbhaḥ na hasta pāda ādi prasāraṇa rūpam sva kāryam karoti na vā svarūpataḥ upalabhyate iti viśeṣaḥ
translated: But a fetus covered by the womb does not perform its own function characterized by stretching out hands, feet, etc., nor is it perceived in its own form. This is the difference.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha.

original: na ca kasyacid evāyaṃ vairy api tu sarvasyaiveti sadṛṣṭāntam āha dhūmeneti /
analyzed: na ca kasyacid eva ayam vairī api tu sarvasya eva iti sa dṛṣṭāntam āha dhūmena iti
translated: And this is not only for some, but for all, he says with an example: by smoke, etc.

original: kāmasyāgāḍhatve gāḍhatve 'tigāḍhatve ca krameṇa dṛṣṭāntāḥ /
analyzed: kāmasya agāḍha tve gāḍha tve tigāḍha tve ca krameṇa dṛṣṭāntāḥ
translated: The examples are in order of the desire being not deep, deep, and very deep.

original: dhūmenāvṛto 'pi malino vahnir dāhādilakṣaṇaṃ svakāryaṃ tu karoti /
analyzed: malinaḥ vahniḥ dāha ādi lakṣaṇam sva kāryam tu karoti
translated: Even though fire is covered by smoke and is dirty, it performs its own function characterized by burning, etc.

original: malenāvṛto darpaṇaṃ tu svacchatādharmatirodhānād bimbagrahaṇaṃ svakāryaṃ na karoti svarūpatas tūpalabhyate /
analyzed: malena āvṛtaḥ darpaṇam tu svaccha tā dharma tirodhānāt bimba grahaṇam sva kāryam na karoti svarūpataḥ tu upalabhyate
translated: A mirror covered by dust, because it obscures the property of clarity, does not perform its own function of reflecting an image, but is still perceived in its own form.

original: ulbena jarāyūṇāvṛto garbhas tu svakāryaṃ karacaraṇādiprasāraṇaṃ na karoti /
analyzed: ulbena jarāyūṇā āvṛtaḥ garbhaḥ tu sva kāryam kara caraṇa ādi prasāraṇam na karoti
translated: An embryo covered by the womb and the placenta does not perform its own function of stretching out its hands, feet, and so on.

original: na vā svarūpata upalabhyata iti /
analyzed: na vā svarūpataḥ upalabhyate iti
translated: Or it is not perceived in its own form.

original: evaṃ kāmasyāgāḍhatve paramārthasmaraṇaṃ kartuṃ śaknoti /
analyzed: evam kāmasya agāḍha tve paramārtha smaraṇam kartum śaknoti
translated: Thus, when desire is not intense, one is able to remember the ultimate truth.

original: gāḍhatve na śaknotīti gāḍhatve tv acetanam eva syād idaṃ jagad eva ////
analyzed: gāḍha tve na śaknoti iti gāḍha tve tu acetanam eva syāt idam jagat eva
translated: When it is intense, one is not able. Therefore, when it is intense, this world would be insentient.

original: baladevaḥ / mṛdumadhyatīvrabhāvena trividhasya kāmasya dhūmamalolbaneti krameṇa dṛṣṭāntān āha dhūmenet /
analyzed: baladevaḥ mṛdu madhya tīvra bhāvena trividhasya kāmasya dhūma mala ulbanā iti krameṇa dṛṣṭāntān āha dhūmena it
translated: Balarama. He gives examples in order for the three types of desire, which are of mild, medium, and intense nature, namely smoke, dust, and womb, respectively, with by smoke and so on.

original: yathā dhūmenāvṛto 'nujjvalo 'pi vahnir auṣṇādikaṃ kiṃcit karoti malenāvṛto darpaṇaḥ
analyzed: yathā dhūmena āvṛtaḥ vahniḥ auṣṇa ādikam kiṃcid karoti malena āvṛtaḥ darpaṇaḥ
translated: Just as a fire covered by smoke, though not very bright, performs some function such as heat, a mirror covered by dust

original: svacchatātirodhānāt pratibimbaṃ na śaknoti grahītum ulbena jarāguṇāvṛto garbhas
analyzed: svaccha tā tirodhānāt pratibimbam na śaknoti grahītum ulbena jarā guṇa āvṛtaḥ garbhaḥ
translated: is not able to reflect an image because it obscures clarity. An embryo covered by the womb and the placenta

original: tu pādādiprasārarṃ na śaknoti kartuṃ na copalabhyate /
analyzed: tu pāda ādi prasārar na śaknoti kartum na ca upalabhyate
translated: is not able to perform the function of stretching out its feet and so on, and is not perceived.

original: tathā mṛdunā kāmenāvṛtaṃ jñānaṃ kathaṃcit tattvārthaṃ grahītuṃ śaknoti madhyenāvṛtaṃ na śaknoti /
analyzed: tathā mṛdunā kāmena āvṛtam jñānam kathaṃcid tattva artham grahītum śaknoti madhyena āvṛtam na śaknoti
translated: Similarly, the knowledge that is covered by mild passion is able to grasp the truth somehow, that covered by moderate passion is not able to do so,

original: tīvreṇāvṛtaṃ tu prasartum api na śaknoti /
analyzed: tīvreṇa āvṛtam tu prasartum api na śaknoti
translated: but that covered by intense passion is not able even to proceed,

original: na ca pratīyata ity arthaḥ ////
analyzed: na ca pratīyate iti arthaḥ
translated: the meaning is that it is not even perceived.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: Bhagavad Gita

original: āvṛtaṃ jñānam etena jñānino nityavairiṇā /
analyzed: āvṛtam jñānam etena jñāninaḥ nitya vairiṇā
translated: The knowledge of the knower is always covered by this enemy,

original: kāmarūpeṇa kaunteya duṣpūreṇānalena ca ////
analyzed: kāmarūpeṇa kaunteya duṣpūreṇa analena ca
translated: in the form of passion, O son of Kunti, which is insatiable and like a fire.

original: śrīdharaḥ / idaṃ śabdanirdiṣṭaṃ darśayan vairitvaṃ sphuṭayati āvṛtam iti /
translated: Sri Sridhara. Pointing out what is indicated by the word 'this', he clarifies its enmity in the verse 'covered'.

original: idaṃ vivekajñānam etena āvṛtam /
analyzed: idam viveka jñānam etena āvṛtam
translated: This discrimination-knowledge is covered by this.

original: ajñasya khalu bhogasamaye kāmaḥ sukhahetur eva /
analyzed: ajñasya khalu bhoga samaye kāmaḥ sukha hetuḥ eva
translated: For the ignorant, indeed, at the time of enjoyment, passion is only the cause of happiness.

original: pariṇāme tu vairitvaṃ pratipadyate /
analyzed: pariṇāme tu vairi tvam pratipadyate
translated: But at the time of transformation, it becomes an enemy.

original: jñāninaḥ punas tatkālam apy anarthānusandhānād duḥkhahetur eveti nitgyavairiṇety uktam /
analyzed: jñāninaḥ punar tad kālam api anartha anusandhānāt duḥkha hetuḥ evā iti nitgyavairiṇā iti uktam
translated: But for the knower, it is only a cause of suffering even at that time because of the apprehension of misfortune. Thus it is said to be an eternal enemy.

original: kiṃ ca viṣayaiḥ pūryamāṇo 'pi yo duṣpūraḥ /
analyzed: kim ca viṣayaiḥ pūryamāṇaḥ yaḥ duṣpūraḥ
translated: Moreover, it is insatiable, even when filled with objects.

original: āpūryamāṇaṃ tu śokasantāpahetutvād analatulyaḥ /
analyzed: āpūryamāṇam tu śoka santāpa hetu tvāt anala tulyaḥ
translated: But when filled, it is like a fire because it is the cause of grief and torment.

original: anena sarvān prati nityavairitvam uktam ////🔽madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: anena sarvān prati nitya vairi tvam uktam 🔽madhusūdanaḥ
translated: By this, it is said that it is an eternal enemy to all.

original: tathā tenedam āvṛtam iti saṅgrahavākyaṃ vivṛṇoty āvṛtam iti /
analyzed: tathā tena idam āvṛtam iti saṅgraha vākyam vivṛṇoti āvṛtam iti
translated: Similarly, he explains the summary statement 'It covers this' with the words 'covered'.

original: jñāyate 'neneti jñānam antaḥkaraṇaṃ vivekavijñānaṃ vedaśabdanirdiṣṭam etena kāmenāvṛtam /
analyzed: jñāyate nena iti jñānam antaḥkaraṇam viveka vijñānam veda śabda nirdiṣṭam etena kāmena āvṛtam
translated: This is known by this, therefore knowledge is the internal organ, the discrimination-knowledge indicated by the word Veda, it is covered by this desire.

original: tathāpy āpātataḥ sukhahetutvād upādeyaḥ syād ity ata āha jñānino nityavairiṇā /
analyzed: tathā api āpātataḥ sukha hetu tvāt upādeyaḥ syāt iti atas āha jñāninaḥ nitya vairiṇā
translated: Even so, it might be accepted as the cause of happiness for the time being. Therefore he says: for the knower, it is an eternal enemy.

original: ajño hi viṣayabhogakāle kāmaṃ mitram iva paśyaṃs tatkārye duḥkhe prāpte vairitvaṃ jānāti kāmenāhaṃ duḥkhitvam āpādita iti /
analyzed: ajñaḥ hi viṣaya bhoga kāle kāmam mitram iva paśyan tad kārye duḥkhe prāpte vairi tvam jānāti kāmena aham duḥkhi tvam āpāditaḥ iti
translated: For the ignorant one, at the time of enjoying objects, seeing desire as a friend, when suffering - its effect - is attained, he knows it to be an enemy, thinking 'Desire has brought me to suffering.'

original: jñānī tu bhogakāle 'pi jānāty anenāham anarthe praveśita iti /
analyzed: jñānī tu bhoga kāle jānāti anena aham anarthe praveśitaḥ iti
translated: But the knower, even at the time of enjoyment, knows 'By this I have been led to misfortune.'

original: ato vivekī duḥkhī bhavati bhogakāle ca tatpariṇāme cāneneti jñānino 'sau nityavairīti sarvathā tena hantavya evety arthaḥ /
analyzed: atas vivekī duḥkhī bhavati bhoga kāle ca tad pariṇāme ca anena iti jñāninaḥ sau nitya vairī iti sarvathā tena hantavyaḥ evā iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the discriminating one suffers at the time of enjoyment and its culmination, thinking 'By this.' Thus, for the knower, it is an eternal enemy. The meaning is that it should be destroyed by him in every way.

original: tarhi kiṃ svarūo 'sāv ity ata āha kāmarūpeṇa /
analyzed: tarhi kim sau iti atas āha kāmarūpeṇa
translated: Then, what is its nature? Therefore he says: in the form of desire.

original: kāma icchā tṛṣṇā saiva rūpaṃ yasya tena /
analyzed: kāmaḥ icchā tṛṣṇā sā eva rūpam yasya tena
translated: Desire is longing, craving. That which has that as its form is by that.

original: he kaunteyeti sambandhāviṣkāreṇa premāṇaṃ sūcayati /
analyzed: he kaunteya iti sambandha āviṣkāreṇa premāṇam sūcayati
translated: O son of Kunti, by expressing the relationship, he indicates affection.

original: nanu vivekino hantavyo 'py avivekina upādeyaḥ syād ity ata āha duṣpūreṇānalena ca /
analyzed: nanu vivekinaḥ hantavyaḥ api avivekinaḥ upādeyaḥ syāt iti atas āha duṣpūreṇa analena ca
translated: Objection: Even though one who is wise should abandon desire, one who is not wise should accept it. In response, the Lord says: and by the fire that is difficult to satisfy.

original: cakāra upamārthaḥ /🔽na vidyate 'laṃ paryāptir yasyety analo vahniḥ /
analyzed: cakāraḥ upamā arthaḥ  na vidyate lam paryāptiḥ yasya iti analaḥ vahniḥ
translated: The word ca (and) is used in the sense of comparison.🔽The word anala means fire, which is not (na) enough (ala) to satisfy.

original: sa yathā haviṣā pūrayitum aśakyas tathāyam api bhogenety arthaḥ /
analyzed: sa yathā haviṣā pūrayitum aśakyaḥ tathā ayam api bhogena iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that just as that fire cannot be satisfied by oblations, so also this desire cannot be satisfied by the enjoyment of objects.

original: ato nirantaraṃ santāpahetutvād vivekina ivāvivekino 'pi heya evāsau /
analyzed: atas nirantaram santāpa hetu tvāt vivekinaḥ iva avivekinaḥ u pi heyaḥ eva asau
translated: Therefore, like one who is wise, even one who is not wise should abandon desire, because it is the cause of continuous torment.

original: tathā ca smṛtiḥ
analyzed: tathā ca smṛtiḥ
translated: And thus it is said in the Smriti:

original: na jātu kāmaḥ kāmānām upabhogena śāṃyati /
analyzed: na jātu kāmaḥ kāmānām upabhogena śāṃyati
translated: Desire is never pacified by the enjoyment of objects of desire.

original: haviṣā kṛṣṇavartmeva bhūya evābhivardhate // BhP / / iti /
analyzed: haviṣā kṛṣṇavartmā iva bhūyas eva abhivardhate     iti
translated: Like a black fire by oblations, it only increases more.

original: athavecchāyā viṣayasiddhinivartyatvād icchārūpaḥ kāmo viṣayabhogena svayam eva nivartiṣyate kiṃ tatrātinirbandhenety ata uktaṃ duṣpūreṇānalena 🔽ceti /
analyzed: athavā icchāyāḥ viṣaya siddhi nivartya tvāt icchā rūpaḥ kāmaḥ viṣaya bhogena svayam eva nivartiṣyate kim tatra ati nirbandhena iti atas uktam duṣpūreṇa analena  ca iti
translated: Or, desire, which is in the form of desire, will be removed by itself through the enjoyment of objects, since desire is removed by the attainment of its object. What is the use of excessive insistence on it? In response, the Lord says: and by the fire that is difficult to satisfy.

original: viṣayasiddhyā tatkālam icchātirodhāne 'pi punaḥ prādurbhāvān na viṣayasiddhir icchānivartikā /
analyzed: viṣaya siddhyā tad kālam icchā tirodhāne punar prādurbhāvāt na viṣaya siddhiḥ icchā nivartikā
translated: The meaning is that even though desire may be temporarily suppressed by the attainment of its object, it reappears again, so the attainment of the object does not remove desire.

original: kintu viṣayadoṣadṛṣṭir evatatheti bhāvaḥ ////
analyzed: kintu viṣaya doṣa dṛṣṭiḥ eva tathā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Rather, it is only the vision of the faults of the object that removes it. This is the idea.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha:

original: kāma eva hi jīvasyāvidyety āha āvṛtam iti /
analyzed: kāmaḥ eva hi jīvasya avidyā iti āha āvṛtam iti
translated: For desire itself is the ignorance of the individual soul. Thus he says, 'covered' etc.

original: nityavairiṇy ato 'sau sarvaprakāreṇa hantavya iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: nitya vairiṇī sau sarva prakāreṇa hantavyaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is an eternal enemy, therefore it should be killed in every way.

original: kāmarūpeṇa kāmākāreṇājñānenety arthaḥ /
analyzed: kāma rūpeṇa kāma ākāreṇa ajñānena iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is by the form of desire, by ignorance in the form of desire.

original: cakāra ivārthe /
analyzed: cakāraḥ iva arthe
translated: The word 'ca' has the meaning of 'iva'.

original: analo yathā haviṣā pūrayitum acakyas tathā kāmo 'pi bhogenety arthaḥ / yad uktam
analyzed: analaḥ yathā haviṣā pūrayitum acakyaḥ tathā kāmaḥ api bhogena iti arthaḥ yat uktam
translated: Just as fire cannot be filled with oblations, so also desire with enjoyment. This is the meaning. As it is said:

original: na jātu kāmaḥ kāmānām upabhogena śāṃyati /
analyzed: na jātu kāmaḥ kāmānām upabhogena śāṃyati
translated: Desire is never pacified by the enjoyment of desires,

original: haviṣā kṛṣṇavartmeva bhūya evābhivardhate // BhP / / iti ////
analyzed: haviṣā kṛṣṇavartmā iva bhūyas eva abhivardhate     iti
translated: like a black-snake by oblations, it only grows more and more.

original: baladevaḥ / uktam arthaṃ sphuṭayati āvṛtam iti /
analyzed: sphuṭayati   iti
translated: Balarama. He clarifies the stated meaning with 'covered' etc.

original: anena kāmarūpeṇa nityavairiṇā jñānino jīvasya jñānam āvṛtam iti sambandhaḥ /
analyzed: anena kāmarūpeṇa nitya vairiṇā jñāninaḥ jīvasya jñānam āvṛtam iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is that the knowledge of the wise individual is covered by this desire in the form of ignorance, which is an eternal enemy.

original: ajñasya viṣayabhogasamaye sukhatvāt suhṛd api kāmas tatkārye duḥkhe sati vairḥ syād vijñasya tu tatsamaye 'pi duḥkhānusandhānād duḥkhahetur
analyzed: ajñasya viṣaya bhoga samaye sukha tvāt suhṛd api kāmaḥ tad kārye duḥkhe sati vairḥ syāt vijñasya tu tad samaye duḥkha anusandhānāt duḥkha hetuḥ
translated: For the ignorant, at the time of enjoying sense objects, it is happiness, so desire is a friend. But when that results in suffering, it becomes an enemy. For the wise, even at that time, it is the cause of suffering because of the recollection of suffering.

original: eveti nityavairiṇety uktiḥ /
analyzed: eva iti nitya vairiṇā iti uktiḥ
translated: Therefore, it is said to be an eternal enemy.

original: tasmāt sarvathā hantavya iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt sarvathā hantavyaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it should be killed in every way.

original: kiṃ ca duṣpūreṇeti /
analyzed: kim ca duṣpūreṇa iti
translated: Moreover, with 'difficult to fill' etc.

original: caśabda ivārthaḥ /
analyzed: caśabdaḥ iva arthaḥ
translated: The word 'ca' (and) has the sense of 'iva' (like).

original: tatrānalo yathā haviṣā pūrayitum aśakyas tathā bhogena kāma ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: tatra analaḥ yathā haviṣā pūrayitum aśakyaḥ tathā bhogena kāmaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Just as fire cannot be filled with oblations, so desire cannot be satisfied with enjoyment, is the meaning.

original: smṛtiś caivam āha
analyzed: smṛtiḥ ca evam āha
translated: And the Smriti says thus:

original: na jātu kāmaḥ kāmānām upabhogena śāṃyati /
analyzed: na jātu kāmaḥ kāmānām upabhogena śāṃyati
translated: Desire is never pacified by the enjoyment of desires,

original: haviṣā kṛṣṇavartmeva bhūya evābhivardhate // BhP / / iti /
analyzed: haviṣā kṛṣṇavartmā iva bhūyas eva abhivardhate     iti
translated: like a fire by oblations; it only grows more and more.

original: tasmāt sarveṣāṃ sa nityavairīti ////
analyzed: tasmāt sarveṣām sa nitya vairī iti
translated: Therefore, he is the eternal enemy of all.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: Bhagavad Gita

original: indriyāṇi mano buddhir asyādhiṣṭhānam ucyate /
analyzed: indriyāṇi manaḥ buddhiḥ asya adhiṣṭhānam ucyate
translated: The senses, the mind and the intellect are said to be its abode.

original: etair vimohayaty eṣa jñānam āvṛtya dehinam ////
analyzed: etaiḥ vimohayati eṣa jñānam āvṛtya dehinam
translated: It deludes the embodied being by covering over his knowledge with these.

original: śrīdharaḥ / idānīṃ tasyādhiṣṭhānaṃ kathayan jayopāyam āha indriyāṇīti dvābhyām /
translated: Sridhar: Now, speaking of its abode, he says in two verses the means of victory.

original: viṣayadarśanaśravaṇādibhiḥ saṃkalpenādhyavasāyena ca kāmasya āvirbhāvād indriyāṇi ca manaś ca buddhiś cāsyādhiṣṭhānam ucyate /
analyzed: viṣaya darśana śravaṇa ādibhiḥ saṃkalpena adhyavasāyena ca kāmasya āvirbhāvāt indriyāṇi ca manaḥ ca buddhiḥ ca asya adhiṣṭhānam ucyate
translated: The senses, the mind and the intellect are said to be its abode, because desire manifests through seeing, hearing and other objects, through imagination and through determination.

original: etair indriyādibhir darśanādivyāpāravadbhir āśrayabhūtair vivekajñānam āvṛtya dehinaṃ vimohayati ////
analyzed: etaiḥ indriya ādibhiḥ darśana ādi vyāpāravadbhiḥ āśraya bhūtaiḥ viveka jñānam āvṛtya dehinam vimohayati
translated: It deludes the embodied being by covering over the knowledge of discrimination with these senses and other things that have the function of seeing and other activities and that are the supports.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana:

original: jñāte hi śatror adhiṣṭhāne sukhena sa jetuṃ śakyata iti tadadhiṣṭhānam āha indriyāṇīti /
analyzed: jñāte hi śatroḥ adhiṣṭhāne sukhena sa jetum śakyate iti tad adhiṣṭhānam āha indriyāṇi iti
translated: For, when the abode of the enemy is known, he can be easily conquered. Therefore, he mentions its abode as the senses.

original: indriyāṇi śabdasparśarūparasagandhagrāhakāṇi śrotrādīni vacanādānagamanavisargānandajanakāni vāgādīni ca /
analyzed: indriyāṇi śabda sparśa rūpa rasa gandha grāhakāṇi śrotra ādīni vacana ādāna gamana visarga ānanda janakāni vāc ādīni ca
translated: The senses are the ears etc. which grasp sound, touch, form, taste and smell, and the speech etc. which produce speech, taking, moving, excretion and pleasure.

original: manaḥ saṅkalpātmakaṃ buddhir adhyavasāyātmikā ca /
analyzed: manaḥ saṅkalpa ātmakam buddhiḥ adhyavasāya ātmikā ca
translated: The mind is of the nature of determination, and the intellect is of the nature of ascertainment.

original: asya kāmasyādhiṣṭhānam āśraya ucyate /
analyzed: asya kāmasya adhiṣṭhānam āśrayaḥ ucyate
translated: The abode, the support, of this desire is said to be.

original: yata etair indriyādibhiḥ svasvavyāpāravadbhir āśrayair vimohayati vividhaṃ mohayati eṣa kāmo jñānam vivekajñānam āvṛtyācchādya dehinaṃ dehābhimāninam
analyzed: yatas etaiḥ indriya ādibhiḥ sva sva vyāpāravadbhiḥ āśrayaiḥ vimohayati vividham mohayati eṣa kāmaḥ jñānam viveka jñānam āvṛtya ācchādya dehinam deha abhimāninam
translated: By these, the senses etc., which are the supports engaged in their respective functions, this desire, having covered, concealed the knowledge, the discrimination-knowledge, of the embodied one, the one who identifies with the body, deludes, confuses him in various ways.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha.

original: kvāsau tiṣṭhaty ata āha indriyāṇīti /
analyzed: kva asau tiṣṭhati atas āha indriyāṇi iti
translated: Where does he stay? Therefore it is said that the senses etc.

original: asya vairiṇaḥ kāmasyādhiṣṭhānaṃ mahādurgarājadhānyaḥ /
analyzed: asya vairiṇaḥ kāmasya adhiṣṭhānam mahā durga rājadhānyaḥ
translated: The abode of this enemy, desire, is the great fortress-capital.

original: śabdādayo viṣayās tu tasya rājño deśā iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: śabda ādayaḥ viṣayāḥ tu tasya rājñaḥ deśāḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The objects like sound etc. are the countries of that king. This is the idea.

original: etair indriyādibhir dehinaṃ jīvam ////
analyzed: etaiḥ indriya ādibhiḥ dehinam jīvam
translated: By these, the senses etc., the embodied one, the living being...🔽...

original: baladevaḥ / vairiṇaḥ kāmasya durgeṣu nirjiteṣu tasya jayaḥ sukara iti tāny āha indriyāṇīti /
analyzed: baladevaḥ vairiṇaḥ kāmasya durgeṣu nirjiteṣu tasya jayaḥ sukaraḥ iti tāni āha indriyāṇi iti
translated: Baladeva: When the forts of the enemy, desire, have been conquered, his victory becomes easy. Therefore, he speaks of them as the senses, etc.

original: viṣayaśravaṇādinā saṅkalpenādhyavasāyena ca kāmasyābhivyakteḥ śrotrādīni ca manaś
analyzed: viṣaya śravaṇa ādinā saṅkalpena adhyavasāyena ca kāmasya abhivyakteḥ śrotra ādīni ca manaḥ
translated: Since desire becomes manifest through hearing objects, etc., through imagination, and through determination, the ear, etc., the mind,

original: ca buddhiś ca tasyādhiṣṭhānaṃ mahādurgarājadhānīrūpaṃ bhavati viṣayās tu tasya
analyzed: ca buddhiḥ ca tasya adhiṣṭhānam mahā durga rājadhānī rūpam bhavati viṣayāḥ tu tasya
translated: and the intellect become the abode of that desire, like the capital of a great fort. But the objects are

original: tasya janapadā bodhyāḥ /
analyzed: tasya janapadāḥ bodhyāḥ
translated: to be understood as the country of that desire.

original: etair viṣayasaṃcāribhir indriyādibhir dehinaṃ prakṛtisṛṣṭadehavantaṃ jīvam ātmajñānodyatam
analyzed: etaiḥ viṣaya saṃcāribhiḥ indriya ādibhiḥ dehinam prakṛti sṛṣṭa dehavantam jīvam ātma jñāna udyatam
translated: By these, which move about in objects, the senses, etc., the embodied one, the individual soul possessing a body created by Prakṛti, who is intent on the knowledge of the Self,

original: eṣa kāmo vimohayati ātmajñānavimukhaṃ viṣayarasapravaṇaṃ ca karotīty arthaḥ // //
analyzed: eṣa kāmaḥ vimohayati ātma jñāna vimukham viṣaya rasa pravaṇam ca karoti iti arthaḥ
translated: this desire deludes, that is, makes him averse to the knowledge of the Self and inclined to the taste of objects.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: BhG 5.13

original: tasmāt tvam indriyāṇy ādau niyamya bharatarṣabha /
analyzed: tasmāt tvam indriyāṇi ādau niyamya bharata ṛṣabha
translated: Therefore, O best of the Bharata lineage, first control the senses,

original: pāpmānaṃ prajahihy enaṃ jñānavijñānanāśanam ////
analyzed: pāpmānam prajahihi enam jñāna vijñāna nāśanam
translated: and abandon this sin, which destroys knowledge and wisdom.

original: śrīdharaḥ / yasmād evaṃ tasmād iti /
translated: Śrīdhara: Since it is so, therefore, etc.

original: tasmād ādau vimohāt pūrvam evendriyāṇi mano buddhiṃ ca niyamya pāpmānaṃ pāparūpam enaṃ kāmaṃ hi sphuṭaṃ prajahi ghātaya /
analyzed: tasmāt ādau vimohāt pūrvam evā indriyāṇi manaḥ buddhim ca niyamya pāpmānam pāpa rūpam enam kāmam hi sphuṭam prajahi ghātaya
translated: Therefore, first, even before delusion, having controlled the senses, the mind and the intellect, do you clearly abandon, do away with, this sin, this lust, which is of the nature of sin.

original: yad vā prajahihi parityaja /
analyzed: yat vā prajahihi parityaja
translated: Or, do you abandon, do away with.

original: jñānam ātmaviṣayaṃ /
analyzed: jñānam ātma viṣayam
translated: Knowledge is that which has the Self as its object.

original: vijñānaṃ nididhyāsanajam /
analyzed: vijñānam nididhyāsana jam
translated: Vijnana is that which arises from meditation.

original: tam eva dhīro vijñāya prajñāṃ kurvīta iti śruteḥ ////
analyzed: tam eva dhīraḥ vijñāya prajñām kurvīta iti śruteḥ
translated: The wise one, having known that alone, should make wisdom.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana.

original: yasmād evam /
analyzed: yasmāt evam
translated: Since it is so.

original: yasmād indriyādhiṣṭhānaḥ kāmo dehinaṃ mohayati tasmāt tvam ādau mohanāt pūrvaṃ kāmanirodhāt pūrvam iti vā /
analyzed: yasmāt indriya adhiṣṭhānaḥ kāmaḥ dehinam mohayati tasmāt tvam ādau mohanāt pūrvam kāma nirodhāt pūrvam iti vā
translated: Since lust, which is based on the senses, deludes the embodied soul, therefore, first, before delusion, or before the cessation of desire,

original: indriyāṇi śrotrādīni niyamya vaśīkṛtya /
analyzed: indriyāṇi śrotra ādīni niyamya vaśīkṛtya
translated: having controlled, having brought under control, the senses such as the ears,

original: teṣu hi vaśīkṛteṣu manobuddhyor api vaśīkaraṇaṃ sidhyati saṅkalpādhyavasāyayor bāhyendriyapravṛttidvāraivānarthahetutvāt /
analyzed: teṣu hi vaśīkṛteṣu manaḥ buddhyoḥ api vaśīkaraṇam sidhyati saṅkalpa adhyavasāyayoḥ bāhya indriya pravṛtti dvārā eva anartha hetu tvāt
translated: for when they are brought under control, the control of the mind and intellect is also accomplished, because intention and determination are the cause of harm only through the operation of the external senses.

original: ata indriyāṇi mano buddhir iti pūrvaṃ pṛthaṅnirdiśyāpīhendriyāṇīty etāvad uktam /
analyzed: atas indriyāṇi manaḥ buddhiḥ iti pūrvam pṛthak nirdiśya api iha indriyāṇi iti etāvat uktam
translated: Therefore, although the senses, the mind and the intellect were mentioned separately earlier, here only the senses are mentioned.

original: indriyatvena tayor api saṅgraho vā /
analyzed: indriya tvena tayoḥ api saṅgrahaḥ vā
translated: Or, they are also included among the senses.

original: he bharatarṣabha mahāvaṃśaprabhūtatvena samartho 'si /
analyzed: he bharata ṛṣabha mahā vaṃśa prabhūta tvena samarthaḥ si
translated: O best of the Bharata race, you are able by the abundance of your great lineage.

original: pāpmānaṃ sarvapāpamūlabhūtam enaṃ kāmaṃ vairiṇaṃ prajahihi parityaja hi sphuṭaṃ prajahi prakarṣeṇa mārayeti vā /
analyzed: pāpmānam sarva pāpa mūla bhūtam enam kāmam vairiṇam prajahihi parityaja hi sphuṭam prajahi prakarṣeṇa māraya iti vā
translated: Abandon, give up, clearly abandon, or completely destroy this desire, which is the root of all sins, this sin, this enemy.

original: jahi śatrum ity upasaṃhārāc ca /
analyzed: jahi śatrum iti upasaṃhārāt ca
translated: And because of the conclusion destroy the enemy.

original: jñānaṃ śāstrācāryopadeśajaṃ parokṣaṃ vijñānam aparokṣaṃ tatphalaṃ tayor jñānavijñānayoḥ śreyaḥprāptihetvor🔽nāśanam ////
analyzed: jñānam śāstra ācārya upadeśa jam parokṣam vijñānam a parokṣam tad phalam tayoḥ jñāna vijñānayoḥ śreyaḥ prāpti hetvoḥ  nāśanam
translated: Knowledge is that which arises from the teachings of scriptures and teachers. Knowledge is indirect, its result is direct. Of these two, knowledge and direct knowledge, which are the causes of attaining the highest good,🔽the destruction of which is...

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha.

original: vairiṇaḥ khalv āśraye jite sati vairī jīyata iti nītir ataḥ kāmasyāśrayeṣv indriyādiṣu yathottaraṃ durjayatvādhikyam /
analyzed: vairiṇaḥ khalu āśraye jite sati vairī jīyate iti nītiḥ atas kāmasya āśrayeṣu indriya ādiṣu yathottaram durjaya tva ādhikyam
translated: The policy is that when the abode of the enemy is conquered, the enemy is conquered. Therefore, the senses and so on, which are the abodes of desire, are increasingly difficult to conquer.

original: ataḥ prathamaprāptānīndriyāṇi durjayāny apy uttarāpekṣayā sujayāni /
analyzed: atas prathama prāptāni indriyāṇi durjayāni api uttara apekṣayā sujayāni
translated: Therefore, the senses, which are the first to be attained, are difficult to conquer, but they are easily conquered in relation to what follows.

original: prathamaṃ te jīyantām ity āha tasmād iti /
analyzed: prathamam te jīyantām iti āha tasmāt iti
translated: Therefore, conquer them first. Thus he says, Therefore...

original: indriyāṇi niyamyena yadyapi parastrīparadravyādyapaharaṇe durnivāraṃ mano gacchaty eva /
analyzed: indriyāṇi niyamyena yadi api para strī para dravya ādi apaharaṇe durnivāram manaḥ gacchati eva
translated: Even though the mind, which is difficult to restrain, goes to steal another's wife, wealth, and so on,

original: tad api tatra tatra netraśrotrakaracaraṇādīndriyavyāpārasthagaṇanād indriyāṇi na gamayety arthaḥ /
analyzed: tat api tatra tatra netra śrotra kara caraṇa ādi indriya vyāpāra stha gaṇanāt indriyāṇi na gamaya iti arthaḥ
translated: That also does not make the senses known, because of the counting of the functions of the senses like eyes, ears, hands, feet, etc. there.

original: pāpmānam atyugraṃ kāmaṃ jahītīndriyavyāpārasthagaṇanam atikālena mano 'pi kāmād vicyutaṃ bhavatīti bhāvaḥ ////
analyzed: pāpmānam ati ugram kāmam jahi iti indriya vyāpāra stha gaṇanam ati kālena manaḥ pi kāmāt vicyutam bhavati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the mind also becomes detached from desire after a long time, because of the counting of the functions of the senses, by which one conquers desire, which is a very fierce evil.🔽The thought is that...

original: baladevaḥ / yasmād ayaṃ kāmarūpo vairī nikhilendriyavyāpāraviratirūpāyātmajñānāyodyatasya
analyzed: baladevaḥ yasmāt ayam kāmarūpaḥ vairī nikhila indriya vyāpāra virati rūpāya ātma jñānāya udyatasya
translated: Balarama: Since this enemy in the form of desire, for one who is striving for the knowledge of the Self in the form of cessation of all the functions of the senses,

original: viṣayarasapravaṇair indriyair jñānam āvṛṇoti tasmāt prakṛtisṛṣṭadehādimāṃs tvam
analyzed: viṣaya rasa pravaṇaiḥ indriyaiḥ jñānam āvṛṇoti tasmāt prakṛti sṛṣṭa deha ādimān tvam
translated: covers the knowledge with the senses inclined towards the taste of objects, therefore, you, who have a body etc. created by Prakriti,

original: ādāv ātmajñānodayāyārambhakāla evendriyāṇi sarvāṇi tadvyāpārarūpe niṣkāme karmayoge
analyzed: ādau ātma jñāna udayāya ārambha kāle eva indriyāṇi sarvāṇi tad vyāpāra rūpe niṣkāme karmayoge
translated: at the very beginning, at the time of starting for the arising of the knowledge of the Self, having restrained all the senses in the form of their functions in the form of desireless Karma Yoga,

original: niyamya pravaṇāni kṛtvā enaṃ pāpmānaṃ kāmaṃ śatruṃ prajahi vināśaya /
analyzed: niyamya pravaṇāni kṛtvā enam pāpmānam kāmam śatrum prajahi vināśaya
translated: having inclined them towards it, conquer, destroy, this enemy in the form of desire, which is evil.

original: hi yasmāj jñānasya śāstrīyasya dehādiviviktātmaviṣayakasya vijñānasya ca tādṛgātmānubhavasya nāśanam āvarakam ////
analyzed: hi yasmāt jñānasya śāstrīyasya deha ādi vivikta ātma viṣayakasya vijñānasya ca tādṛś ātma anubhavasya nāśanam āvarakam
translated: For, it is the destroyer, the concealer, of knowledge, which is scriptural, having the Self, which is distinct from the body etc., as its object, and of the knowledge, which is the experience of such a Self.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: BhG.

original: indriyāṇi parāṇy āhur indriyebhyaḥ paraṃ manaḥ /
analyzed: indriyāṇi parāṇi āhuḥ indriyebhyaḥ param manaḥ
translated: The senses are said to be supreme, and the mind is said to be superior to the senses.

original: manasas tu parā buddhir yo buddheḥ paratas tu saḥ ////
analyzed: manasaḥ tu parā buddhiḥ yaḥ buddheḥ paratas tu saḥ
translated: But the intellect is higher than the mind, and He is higher than the intellect.

original: śrīdharaḥ / yatra cittapraṇidhānena indriyāṇi niyantuṃ śakyante /
translated: Śrīdhara: Where, by fixing the mind, the senses can be controlled.

original: tad ātmasvarūpaṃ dehādibhyo vivicya darśayati indriyāṇīti /
analyzed: tat ātma svarūpam deha ādibhyaḥ vivicya darśayati indriyāṇi iti
translated: He shows the nature of the Self, distinguishing it from the body etc., with the words the senses.

original: indriyāṇi dehādibhyo grāhyebhyaḥ parāṇi śreṣṭhāny āhuḥ sūkṣmatvāt prakāśakatvāc ca /
analyzed: indriyāṇi deha ādibhyaḥ grāhyebhyaḥ parāṇi śreṣṭhāni āhuḥ sūkṣma tvāt prakāśaka tvāt ca
translated: They say that the senses are higher, superior, to the objects like the body etc., because they are subtle and illuminating.

original: ataeva tadvyatiriktatvam apy arthād uktaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: ataeva tad vyatirikta tvam api arthāt uktam bhavati
translated: For this very reason, being distinct from them is also implied.

original: indriyebhyaś ca saṅkalpātmakaṃ manaḥ param tatpravartakatvāt /
analyzed: indriyebhyaḥ ca saṅkalpa ātmakam manaḥ param tad pravartaka tvāt
translated: And the mind, which is of the nature of resolution, is higher than the senses, because it is their instigator.

original: manasas tu niścayātmikā buddhiḥ parā /
analyzed: manasaḥ tu niścaya ātmikā buddhiḥ parā
translated: But the intellect, which is of the nature of determination, is higher than the mind.

original: niścayapūrvakatvāt saṅkalpasya /
analyzed: niścaya pūrvaka tvāt saṅkalpasya
translated: Because resolution is preceded by determination.

original: yas tu buddheḥ paratas tatsākṣitvenāvasthitaḥ sarvāntaraḥ sa ātmā /
analyzed: yaḥ tu buddheḥ paratas tad sākṣi tvena avasthitaḥ sarva antaraḥ saḥ ātmā
translated: But He who is higher than the intellect, abiding as its witness, the innermost of all, is the Self.

original: taṃ vimohayati dehinam iti dehiśabdokta ātmā sa iti parāmṛśyate ////
analyzed: tam vimohayati dehinam iti dehi śabda uktaḥ ātmā saḥ iti parāmṛśyate
translated: He deludes the embodied one. The Self referred to by the word embodied one is referred to by the word He.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusūdana:

original: nanu yathā kathaṃcid bāhyendriyaniyamasambhave 'py āntaratṛṣṇātyāgo 'tiduṣkara iti cen / na /
analyzed: nanu yathā kathaṃcid bāhya indriya niyama sambhave pi āntara tṛṣṇā tyāgaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that even if the control of the external senses is somehow possible, the renunciation of internal craving is extremely difficult, it is not so.

original: raso 'py asya paraṃ dṛṣṭvā nivartate Gītā / ity atra paradarśanasya rasābhidhānīyakatṛṣṇātyāgasādhanasya prāgukteḥ /
analyzed: rasaḥ api asya param dṛṣṭvā nivartate gītā iti atra para darśanasya rasa abhidhānīyaka tṛṣṇā tyāga sādhanasya prāgukteḥ
translated: And the juice also, having seen the supreme, turns back. Here, the seeing of the supreme is mentioned before as the means of abandoning the thirst that is to be called juice.

original: tarhi ko 'sau paro yaddarśanāt tṛṣṇānivṛttir ity āśaṅkya śuddham ātmānaṃ paraśabdavācyaṃ dehādibhyo vivicya darśayati indriyāṇīti /
analyzed: tarhi kaḥ sau paraḥ yad darśanāt tṛṣṇā nivṛttiḥ iti āśaṅkya śuddham ātmānam para śabda vācyam deha ādibhyaḥ vivicya darśayati indriyāṇi iti
translated: Then, what is that supreme by seeing which there is cessation of thirst? Anticipating this doubt, he shows the pure self, denoted by the word 'supreme', distinguished from the body etc.: the senses etc.

original: śrotrādīni jñānendriyāṇi pañca sthūlaṃ jaḍaṃ paricchinnaṃ bāhyaṃ ca deham apekṣya parāṇi sūkṣmatvāt prakāśakatvād vyāpakatvād antaḥsthatvāc 🔽ca prakṛṣṭāny āhuḥ paṇḍitāḥ śrutayo vā /🔽tathendriyebhyaḥ paraṃ manaḥ saṅkalpavikalpātmakaṃ tatpravartakatvāt /🔽tathā manasas tu parā buddhir adhyavasāyātmikā /
analyzed: śrotra ādīni jñāna indriyāṇi pañca sthūlam jaḍam paricchinnam bāhyam ca deham apekṣya parāṇi sūkṣma tvāt prakāśaka tvāt vyāpaka tvāt antar stha tvāt  ca prakṛṣṭāni āhuḥ paṇḍitāḥ śrutayaḥ vā  tathā indriyebhyaḥ param manaḥ saṅkalpa vikalpa ātmakam tad pravartaka tvāt  tathā manasaḥ tu parā buddhiḥ adhyavasāya ātmikā
translated: The wise ones, or the scriptures, say that the five sense organs such as hearing are supreme in relation to the gross, inert, limited, external body, because they are subtle, illuminating, all-pervading, and internal.🔽Similarly, the mind is supreme over the senses, because it is the initiator of the functions of resolution and deliberation.🔽Similarly, the intellect is supreme over the mind, because it is of the nature of determination.

original: adhyavasāyo hi niścayas tatpūrvaka eva saṅkalpādir manodharmaḥ
analyzed: adhyavasāyaḥ hi niścayaḥ tad pūrvakaḥ eva saṅkalpa ādiḥ manaḥ dharmaḥ
translated: For determination is the ascertainment that precedes the mental function of resolution etc.

original: yas tu buddheḥ paratas tadbhāsakatvenāvasthito yaṃ dehinam indriyādibhir āśrayair yuktaḥ kāmo jñānāvaraṇadvāreṇa mohayatīty uktaṃ sa buddher
analyzed: yaḥ tu buddheḥ paratas tad bhāsaka tvena avasthitaḥ yam dehinam indriya ādibhiḥ āśrayaiḥ yuktaḥ kāmaḥ jñāna āvaraṇa dvāreṇa mohayati iti uktam sa buddheḥ
translated: But he who is beyond the intellect, who abides as its illuminator, whom the embodied being, endowed with sense organs etc. as supports, desire deludes through the door of obscuring knowledge, he is the supreme Self, the seer of the intellect.

original: draṣṭā para ātmā /
analyzed: draṣṭā para ātmā
translated: He is the supreme Self.

original: sa eṣa iha praviṣṭaḥ itivad dvyavahitasyāpi dehinas tadā parāmarśaḥ /
analyzed: saḥ eṣaḥ iha praviṣṭaḥ iti vat dvi avahitasya api dehinaḥ tadā parāmarśaḥ
translated: Even though two steps removed, the embodied being is referred to then as He who is within this (Ka. Up. 1.2.23).

original: atrārthe śrutiḥ
analyzed: atra arthe śrutiḥ
translated: In this matter, the Śruti says:

original: indriyebhyaḥ parā hy arthā arthebhyaś ca paraṃ manaḥ /
analyzed: indriyebhyaḥ parāḥ hi arthāḥ arthebhyaḥ ca param manaḥ
translated: The objects are indeed higher than the sense organs, and the mind is higher than the objects.

original: manasas tu parā buddhir buddher ātmā mahān paraḥ //
analyzed: manasaḥ tu parā buddhiḥ buddheḥ ātmā mahān paraḥ
translated: But the intellect is higher than the mind, and the great Self is higher than the intellect.

original: mahataḥ paramavyaktam avyaktāt puruṣaḥ paraḥ /
analyzed: mahataḥ param avyaktam avyaktāt puruṣaḥ paraḥ
translated: The unmanifest is higher than the great, and the Puruṣa is higher than the unmanifest.

original: puruṣān na paraṃ kiṃcit sā kāṣṭhā sā parā gatiḥ // KaṭhU / / iti /🔽atrātmanaḥ paratvasyaiva vākyatātparyaviṣayatvād indriyādiparatvasyāvivakṣitatvād
analyzed: puruṣāt na param kiṃcid sā kāṣṭhā sā parā gatiḥ kaṭhu iti  atra ātmanaḥ paratvasya eva vākya tātparya viṣayatvāt indriya ādi paratvasya avivakṣita tvāt
translated: There is nothing higher than the Puruṣa; that is the ultimate, that is the supreme goal. (Ka. Up. 1.3.11)🔽Here, since the supreme nature of the Self alone is the subject matter of the sentence, and since the supremacy of the sense organs etc. is not intended,

original: indriyebhyaḥ parā arthā iti sthāne 'rthebhyaḥ parāṇīndriyāṇīti vivakṣābhedena bhagavaduktaṃ na virudhyate /
analyzed: indriyebhyaḥ parāḥ arthāḥ iti sthāne rthebhyaḥ parāṇi indriyāṇi iti vivakṣā bhedena bhagavat uktam na virudhyate
translated: the statement of the Lord, The objects are indeed higher than the sense organs, is not contradicted by the alternative view that The sense organs are higher than the objects.

original: buddher asmadādivyaṣṭibuddheḥ sakāśān mahān ātmā samaṣṭibuddhirūpaḥ paraḥ mano mahān matir brahma pūr buddhiḥ khyātir īśvaraḥ iti vāyupurāṇavacanāt
analyzed: buddheḥ asmat ādi vyaṣṭi buddheḥ sakāśāt mahān ātmā samaṣṭi buddhi rūpaḥ paraḥ manaḥ mahān matiḥ brahma pūḥ buddhiḥ khyātiḥ īśvaraḥ iti vāyupurāṇa vacanāt
translated: The great Self, in the form of the universal intellect, is higher than the individual intellects of persons like us. This is because of the statement in the Vayu Purana: The mind, the great, the intellect, Brahman, the primordial, the intellect, the fame, the Lord.

original: mahato hairaṇyagarbhyā buddheḥ param avyaktam avyākṛtaṃ sarvajagadbījaṃ māyākhyaṃ māyāṃ tu prakṛtiṃ vidyād iti śruteḥ /
analyzed: mahataḥ hairaṇyagarbhyāḥ buddheḥ param avyaktam avyākṛtam sarva jagat bījam māyā ākhyam māyām tu prakṛtim vidyāt iti śruteḥ
translated: Higher than the great intellect of Hiranyagarbha is the unmanifest, called Maya, the seed of the entire world, because of the Vedic statement: One should know Maya as Prakriti.

original: tad dhedaṃ tarhy avyākṛtam āsīt iti ca /
analyzed: tat ha idam tarhi a vyākṛtam āsīt iti ca
translated: And also because of the statement: Then indeed, at that time, it was unmanifest.

original: avyaktāt sakāśāt sakalajaḍavargaprakāśakaḥ puruṣaḥ pūrṇa ātmā paraḥ /
analyzed: avyaktāt sakāśāt sakala jaḍa varga prakāśakaḥ puruṣaḥ pūrṇaḥ ātmā paraḥ
translated: From the unmanifest, the Purusha, the illuminator of the entire class of inert objects, the complete Self, is higher.

original: tasmād api kaścid anyaḥ paraḥ syād ity ata āha puruṣān na paraṃ kiṃcid iti /
analyzed: tasmāt api kaścid anyaḥ paraḥ syāt iti atas āha puruṣāt na param kiṃcid iti
translated: Since it is said that something else may be higher than that, it is said: There is nothing higher than the Purusha.

original: kuta evaṃ yasmāt sā kāṣṭhā samāptiḥ sarvādhiṣṭhānatvāt
analyzed: kutas evam yasmāt sā kāṣṭhā samāptiḥ sarva adhiṣṭhāna tvāt
translated: Why is it so? Because that is the ultimate end, because of being the basis of all.

original: sā parā gatiḥ /
analyzed: sā parā gatiḥ
translated: That is the highest goal.

original: so 'dhvanaḥ pāram āpnoti tad viṣṇoḥ paramaṃ padam ity ādiśrutiprasiddhā parā gatir api saivety arthaḥ /
analyzed: saḥ dhvanaḥ pāram āpnoti tat viṣṇoḥ paramam padam iti ādi śruti prasiddhā parā gatiḥ api sā eva iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that that alone is the well-known highest goal, as stated in the Vedic statements such as: He attains the other shore of the path, that is the highest abode of Vishnu.

original: tad etat sarvaṃ yo buddheḥ paratas tu sa ity anenoktam ////
analyzed: tat etat sarvam yaḥ buddheḥ paratas tu saḥ iti anena uktam
translated: All this is stated by the words But He is higher than the intellect.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha.

original: na ca prathamam eva manobuddhijaye yatanīyam aśakyatvād ity āha indriyāṇi parāṇīti /
analyzed: na ca prathamam eva manaḥ buddhi jaye yatanīyam aśakya tvāt iti āha indriyāṇi parāṇi iti
translated: And it is not that one should strive first of all to conquer the mind and intellect, because that is impossible. He says: The senses are supreme.

original: daśadigvijayibhir api vīrair durjayatvād atibalatvena śreṣṭhānīty arthaḥ /
analyzed: daśa diś vijayibhiḥ api vīraiḥ durjaya tvāt ati bala tvena śreṣṭhāni iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that they are superior due to their great strength, because they are difficult to conquer even by heroes who have conquered the ten directions.

original: indriyebhyaḥ sakāśād api prabalatvān manaḥ paraṃ /
analyzed: indriyebhyaḥ sakāśāt api prabala tvāt manaḥ param
translated: The mind is superior even to the senses, because it is stronger.

original: svapne khalv indriyeṣv api naṣṭeṣv anaśvaratvād iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: svapne khalu indriyeṣu api naṣṭeṣu anaśvara tvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that in a dream, even when the senses are destroyed, it [the mind] does not perish.

original: manasaḥ sakāśād api parā prabalā buddhir vijñānarūpā /
analyzed: manasaḥ sakāśāt api parā prabalā buddhiḥ vijñāna rūpā
translated: The intellect, which is in the form of knowledge, is superior even to the mind, because it is stronger.

original: suṣuptau manasy api naṣṭe tasyāḥ sāmānyākārāyā anaśvarātvād iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: suṣuptau manasi api naṣṭe tasyāḥ sāmānya ākārāyāḥ anaśvara a tvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that in deep sleep, even when the mind is destroyed, it [the intellect] does not perish, because it is in the form of a universal.

original: tasya buddheḥ sakāśād api parato balādhikyena yo vartate /
analyzed: tasya buddheḥ sakāśāt api paratas bala ādhikyena yaḥ vartate
translated: He who is superior to that intellect, who is stronger,

original: tawsyām api jñānābhyāsena naṣṭāyāṃ satyāṃ yo virājata ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: api jñāna abhyāsena naṣṭāyām satyām yaḥ virājate iti arthaḥ
translated: the meaning is that he shines even when that [intellect] is destroyed by the practice of knowledge.

original: sa tu prasiddho jīvātmā kāmasya jetā /
analyzed: sa tu prasiddhaḥ jīvātmā kāmasya jetā
translated: That is the well-known individual soul, the conqueror of desire.

original: tena vastutaḥ sarvato 'py atiprabalena jīvātmanā indriyādīn vijitya kāmo vijetuṃ śakya eveti nātrāsambhāvanā kāryeti bhāvaḥ ////
analyzed: tena vastutas sarvatas pi ati prabalena jīvātmanā indriya ādīn vijitya kāmaḥ vijetum śakyaḥ eva iti na atra asambhāvanā kāryā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that desire can indeed be conquered by that [soul], which is actually stronger than everything, by conquering the senses and so on. No doubt should be entertained in this matter.

original: baladevaḥ / nanu mudritayantrāmbunyāyena niṣkāmakarmapravaṇatayendriyaniyamane kāmakṣatir iti tvayā pradarśitam /
analyzed: baladevaḥ nanu mudrita yantra ambu nyāyena niṣkāma karma pravaṇa tayā indriya niyamane kāma kṣatiḥ iti tvayā pradarśitam
translated: Balarāma: Now, you have shown that by restraining the senses in order to incline towards action without desire, like a water-wheel that has been stopped, desire is destroyed.

original: atha daihikakarmakāle muktayantrāmbunyāyenendriyavṛttiprasāre kāmasya punar🔽ujjīvatāpattiḥ syād iti tatra raso 'py asya paraṃ dṛṣṭvā Gītā / iti pūrvopadiṣṭena
analyzed: atha daihika karma kāle mukta yantra ambu nyāyena indriya vṛtti prasāre kāmasya punar  ujjīva tā āpattiḥ syāt iti tatra asya param dṛṣṭvā gītāḥ iti pūrva upadiṣṭena
translated: Then, at the time of bodily action, like a water-wheel that has been released, when the functioning of the senses spreads out, the return of desire to life

original: viviktātmānubhavena niḥśeṣā tasya kṣatiḥ syād iti darśayati indriyāṇīti dvābhyām /
analyzed: vivikta ātma anubhavena niḥśeṣā tasya kṣatiḥ syāt iti darśayati indriyāṇi iti dvābhyām
translated: would occur. To show that by the previously taught experience of the distinct Self, Seeing the Supreme, even his taste for that is destroyed, as stated in the Gītā, he shows by the next two verses that its complete destruction occurs.

original: pāñcabhautikād dehād indriyāṇi parāṇy āhur paṇḍitāḥ /
analyzed: pāñcabhautikāt dehāt indriyāṇi parāṇi āhuḥ paṇḍitāḥ
translated: The wise say that the senses are superior to the body composed of the five elements.

original: tac cālīkatvāt tato 'tisūkṣmatvāt tadvināśe 'vināśāc ca /
analyzed: tat ca alīka tvāt ti sūkṣma tvāt tad vināśe vināśāt ca
translated: And that is because it is false, more subtle than that, and indestructible when that is destroyed.

original: indriyebhyaḥ manaḥ paraṃ jāgare teṣāṃ pravartakatvāt svapne teṣu svasmin vilīneṣu rājyakartṛtvena sthitatvāc ca /
analyzed: indriyebhyaḥ manaḥ param jāgare teṣām pravartaka tvāt svapne teṣu svasmin vilīneṣu rājya kartṛ tvena sthita tvāt ca
translated: The mind is superior to the senses, because in the waking state they are impelled by it, and in the dream state it exists as the ruler when they have dissolved into itself.

original: manasas tu buddhiḥ parā /
analyzed: manasaḥ tu buddhiḥ parā
translated: But the intellect is superior to the mind.

original: niścayātmakabuddhivṛttyaiva saṅkalpātmakamanovṛtteḥ prasarāt /
analyzed: niścaya ātmaka buddhi vṛttyā eva saṅkalpa ātmaka manaḥ vṛtteḥ prasarāt
translated: Because the functioning of the mind as intention spreads out only through the functioning of the intellect as ascertainment.

original: yas tu buddher api parato 'sti /
analyzed: yaḥ tu buddheḥ api paratas sti
translated: But there is something superior even to the intellect.

original: sa dehī jīvātmā citsvarūpo dehādibuddhyantarviviktayānubhūtaḥ san niḥśeṣakāmakṣatihetur bhavatīti /
analyzed: sa dehī jīvātmā cit svarūpaḥ deha ādi buddhi antar viviktayā anubhūtaḥ san niḥśeṣa kāma kṣati hetuḥ bhavati iti
translated: That embodied individual soul, which is of the nature of consciousness, when experienced as distinct from the notions of the body etc., becomes the cause of the destruction of all desires.

original: kaṭhāś caivaṃ paṭhanti
analyzed: kaṭhāḥ ca evam paṭhanti
translated: And the Katha Upanishad also reads thus:

original: indriyebhyaḥ parā hy arthā arthebhyaś ca paraṃ manaḥ /
analyzed: indriyebhyaḥ parāḥ hi arthāḥ arthebhyaḥ ca param manaḥ
translated: The objects are superior to the senses, the mind is superior to the objects,

original: manasas tu parā buddhir buddher ātmā mahān paraḥ // ity ādi /
analyzed: manasaḥ tu parā buddhiḥ buddheḥ ātmā mahān paraḥ iti ādi
translated: but the intellect is superior to the mind, and the great Self is superior to the intellect.

original: asyārthaḥ indriyebhyo 'rthā viṣayās tadākarsiktatvāt parāḥ pradhānabhūtāḥ /🔽viṣayendriyavyavahārasya manomūlatvād arthebhyo manaḥ paraṃ viṣayabhogasya niścayapūrvakatvāt🔽saṃśayātmakān manaso manaḥ paraṃ viṣayabhogasya niścayapūrvakatvāt saṃśayātmakān
analyzed: asya arthaḥ indriyebhyaḥ rthāḥ viṣayāḥ tad ākarsikta tvāt parāḥ pradhāna bhūtāḥ  viṣaya indriya vyavahārasya manaḥ mūla tvāt arthebhyaḥ manaḥ param viṣaya bhogasya niścaya pūrvaka tvāt  saṃśaya ātmakān manasaḥ manaḥ param viṣaya bhogasya niścaya pūrvaka tvāt saṃśaya ātmakān
translated: The meaning of this is: The objects, which are the sense objects, are superior to the senses, because they attract the senses.🔽Since the functioning of the senses and objects has the mind as its root, the mind is superior to the objects. Since the enjoyment of sense objects is preceded by certainty,

original: manaso niścayātmikā buddhiḥ parā buddher bhogopakaraṇatvāt tasyāḥ sakāśād bhoktātmā🔽jīvaḥ paraḥ sa cātmā mahān dehendriyāntaḥkaraṇasvāmīti daihikaṃ karma tu pūrvābhyāsavaśāc
analyzed: manasaḥ niścaya ātmikā buddhiḥ parā buddheḥ bhoga upakaraṇa tvāt tasyāḥ sakāśāt bhoktā ātmā  jīvaḥ paraḥ sa ca ātmā mahān deha indriya antaḥkaraṇa svāmī iti daihikam karma tu pūrva abhyāsa vaśāt
translated: the intellect, which is of the nature of certainty, is superior to the mind, which is of the nature of doubt. Since the intellect is the instrument of enjoyment, the Self,🔽which is the enjoyer, is superior to the intellect. And that Self is the great one, the lord of the body, senses, internal organs. But the bodily actions will be accomplished

original: cakrabhramitvat setsyati // //
analyzed: cakra bhrami tvat setsyati
translated: by the power of previous practice, like the whirling of a wheel.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: (Katha Upanishad 1.3.10)

original: evaṃ buddheḥ paraṃ buddhvā saṃstabhyātmānam ātmanā /
analyzed: evam buddheḥ param buddhvā saṃstabhya ātmānam ātmanā
translated: Having thus known the Self which is beyond the intellect, and having steadied the mind by the Self,

original: jahi śatruṃ mahābāho kāmarūpaṃ durāsadam ////
analyzed: jahi śatrum mahā bāho kāma rūpam durāsadam
translated: destroy the enemy, O mighty-armed one, which is desire, which assumes any form, and which is difficult to conquer.

original: śrīdharaḥ / upasaṃharati evam iti /
translated: Sri Sridhara: He concludes with Thus.

original: buddher eva viṣayendriyādijanyāḥ kāmādivikriyāḥ /
analyzed: buddheḥ eva viṣaya indriya ādi janyāḥ kāma ādi vikriyāḥ
translated: The modifications of desire etc. are produced by the objects of the senses etc. of the intellect itself.

original: ātmā tu nirvikāras tatsākṣīty evaṃ buddheḥ paramātmānaṃ buddhvātmanaivaṃ tṛtayā niściyātmikayā buddhyātmānaṃ manaḥ saṃstabhya niścalaṃ kṛtvā
analyzed: ātmā tu nirvikāraḥ tad sākṣī iti evam buddheḥ paramātmānam buddhvā ātmanā evam tṛtayā niściyā ātmikayā buddhyā ātmānam manaḥ saṃstabhya niścalam kṛtvā
translated: The Self, however, is changeless, being the witness of that. Having thus known the Supreme Self which is beyond the intellect, having steadied the mind by the Self, by the intellect which is of the nature of firm conviction,

original: kāmarūpiṇaṃ śatruṃ jahi māraya /
analyzed: kāmarūpiṇam śatrum jahi māraya
translated: destroy, kill, the enemy which assumes any form.

original: durāsadaṃ duḥkhenāsādanīyaṃ durvijñeyam ity arthaḥ ////
analyzed: durāsadam duḥkhena āsādanīyam durvijñeyam iti arthaḥ
translated: It is difficult to conquer, difficult to attain by mere effort, difficult to know, is the meaning.

original: svadharmeṇa yam ārādhya bhaktyā muktim itā budhāḥ /
analyzed: svadharmeṇa yam ārādhya bhaktyā muktim itāḥ budhāḥ
translated: Having propitiated Him by one's own duty with devotion, the wise have attained liberation.

original: tat kṛṣṇaṃ paramānandaṃ toṣayet sarvakarmabhiḥ //🔽iti śrīdharasvāmikṛtāyāṃ bhagavadgītāṭīkāyāṃ subodhinyāṃ
analyzed: tat kṛṣṇam parama ānandam toṣayet sarva karmabhiḥ  iti śrīdhara svāmi kṛtāyām bhagavadgītā ṭīkāyām subodhinyām
translated: One should please that Krishna, who is supreme bliss, with all actions.

original: karmayogo nāma tṛtīyo 'dhyāyaḥ ////
analyzed: karmayogaḥ nāma tṛtīyaḥ dhyāyaḥ
translated: Thus ends the third chapter named Karma-yoga in the commentary called Subodhini on the Bhagavad-Gita composed by Sri Sridhara Svami.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana:

original: phalitam āha evam iti /
analyzed: phalitam āha evam iti
translated: He states the conclusion with Thus.

original: raso 'py asya paraṃ dṛṣṭvā nivartate ity atra yaḥ paraśabdenoktas tam evambhūtaṃ
analyzed: rasaḥ api asya param dṛṣṭvā nivartate iti atra yaḥ para śabdena uktaḥ tam evambhūtam
translated: And the taste also, seeing something higher, turns back. Here, that which is spoken of by the word 'higher' is such.

original: pūrṇam ātmānaṃ buddheḥ paraṃ buddhvā sākṣātkṛtya saṃstabhya sthirītkṛtyātmānaṃ mana
analyzed: pūrṇam ātmānam buddheḥ param buddhvā sākṣātkṛtya saṃstabhya sthirītkṛtya ātmānam manaḥ
translated: Having realized, having directly known, that complete Self which is higher than the intellect, having stabilized, having made firm, the mind

original: ātmanaitādṛśaniścayātmkiayā buddhyā jahi māraya śatruṃ sarvapuruṣārthaśātanaṃ
analyzed: ātmanā etādṛśa niścaya ātmkiayā buddhyā jahi māraya śatrum sarva puruṣa artha śātanam
translated: with the intellect which has such a conviction, O mighty-armed one, kill, destroy, the enemy who destroys all human goals.

original: he mahābāho mahābāhor hi śatrumāraṇaṃ sukaram iti yogyaṃ sambodhanam /
analyzed: he mahā bāho mahā bāhoḥ hi śatru māraṇam sukaram iti yogyam sambodhanam
translated: O mighty-armed one, it is easy for one with mighty arms to kill an enemy, thus the address is appropriate.

original: kāmarūpaṃ tṛṣṇārūpaṃ durāsadaṃ duḥkhenāsādanīyaṃ durvijñeyānekaviśeṣam iti yatnādhikyāya viśeṣaṇam ////🔽iti śrīmatparamahaṃsaparivrājakācāryaśrīviśveśvarasarasvatīpādaśiṣyaśrīmadhusūdanasarasvatīviracitāyāṃ śrīmadbhagavadgītāgūḍhārthadīpikāyām 🔽karmayogo nāma
analyzed: kāma rūpam tṛṣṇā rūpam durāsadam duḥkhena āsādanīyam durvijñeya aneka viśeṣam iti yatna ādhikyāya viśeṣaṇam  iti śrīmat paramahaṃsa parivrājaka ācārya śrī viśveśvara sarasvatī pāda śiṣya śrī madhusūdana sarasvatī viracitāyām śrīmat bhagavadgītā gūḍha artha dīpikāyām  karma yogaḥ nāma
translated: The form of desire, which is difficult to approach, difficult to attain through suffering, and has many difficult-to-understand distinctions, this is a qualification for the sake of emphasizing the effort.

original: tṛtīyo 'dhyāyaḥ ////
analyzed: tṛtīyaḥ dhyāyaḥ
translated: Thus ends the third chapter named Karma-yoga in the Gītā-gūḍha-padārtha-dīpikā composed by the illustrious Madhusūdana Sarasvatī, the disciple of the illustrious Viśveśvara Sarasvatī, the preceptor of the Śrīmat Paramahaṃsa Parivrājakācāryas.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Viśvanātha.

original: upasaṃharati evam iti /
analyzed: upasaṃharati evam iti
translated: He concludes with Thus.

original: buddheḥ paraṃ jīvātmānaṃ buddhvā sarvopādhibhyaḥ pṛthakbhūtaṃ jñātvā ātmanā svenaivāmānaṃ svaṃ saṃstabhya niścalaṃ kṛtvā durāsadaṃ durjayam
analyzed: buddheḥ param jīvātmānam buddhvā sarva upādhibhyaḥ pṛthak bhūtam jñātvā ātmanā svena eva amānam svam saṃstabhya niścalam kṛtvā durāsadam durjayam  /
translated: Having known the individual self, which is superior to the intellect, as separate from all limiting adjuncts, having known it, having made one's own self, which is difficult to approach and conquer, firm, unmoving, by one's own self alone, O mighty-armed one, destroy, annihilate, even that desire, which is the enemy in the form of desire.

original: api kāmaṃ jahi nāśaya ////🔽adhyāye 'smin sādhanasya niṣkāmasyaiva karmaṇaḥ /
analyzed: api kāmam jahi nāśaya  adhyāye smin sādhanasya niṣkāmasya eva karmaṇaḥ
translated: Destroy it, annihilate it.

original: prādhānyam ūce tatsādhyajñānasya guṇatāṃ vadan //🔽iti sārārthadarśinyāṃ harṣiṇyāṃ bhaktacetasām /
analyzed: prādhānyam ūce tad sādhya jñānasya guṇa tām vadan  iti sāra artha darśinyām harṣiṇyām bhakta cetasām
translated: In this chapter, speaking of the subordinate nature of the knowledge that is to be accomplished, he has declared the preeminence of the very means, namely, action without desire for fruits.🔽Thus ends the third chapter of the Bhagavad Gita, which is full of meaning, delightful to the minds of the devotees,

original: tṛtīyaḥ khalu gītāsu saṅgataḥ saṅgataḥ satām ////
analyzed: tṛtīyaḥ khalu gītāsu saṅgataḥ saṅgataḥ satām
translated: and which is always dear to the good people.

original: baladevaḥ / evam iti /🔽evaṃ madupadeśavidhayā buddheś ca paraṃ dehādinikhilajaḍavargapravartakatvād viviktaṃ sukhacidghanaṃ jīvātmānaṃ buddhvānubhūyety arthaḥ
analyzed: baladevaḥ evam iti  evam mad upadeśa vidhayā buddheḥ ca param deha ādi nikhila jaḍa varga pravartaka tvāt viviktam sukha cit ghanam jīvātmānam buddhvā anubhūya iti arthaḥ
translated: Balarama. Thus.

original: ātmanā īdṛśaniścayātmikayā buddhyātmānaṃ manaḥ saṃstabhya tādṛśy ātmani sthiraṃ kṛtvā kāmarūpaṃ śatruṃ jahi nāśaya /🔽durāsadaṃ durdharṣam api /
analyzed: ātmanā īdṛśa niścaya ātmikayā buddhyā ātmānam manaḥ saṃstabhya tādṛśi ātmani sthiram kṛtvā kāma rūpam śatrum jahi nāśaya  durāsadam durdharṣam api
translated: In this way, having known, having experienced, the individual self, which is separate from the intellect and the entire group of inert things like the body, etc., because it is the instigator, and which is a mass of blissful consciousness, having made the mind firm, stable, in that way, in the self, by the intellect in the form of such a conviction, O mighty-armed one, destroy, annihilate, even that desire, which is the enemy in the form of desire.🔽Even though it is difficult to approach and conquer.

original: mahābāho iti prāgvat ////
analyzed: mahā bāho iti prāgvat
translated: O mighty-armed one, as before.

original: niṣkāmaṃ karma mukhyaṃ syād gauṇaṃ jñānaṃ tadudbhavam /
analyzed: niṣkāmam karma mukhyam syāt gauṇam jñānam tad udbhavam
translated: Action without desire for fruits would be primary, and knowledge arising from that would be secondary.

original: jīvātmadṛṣṭāv ity eṣa tṛtīyo 'dhyāyanirṇayaḥ //
analyzed: jīvātma dṛṣṭau iti eṣa tṛtīyaḥ dhyāya nirṇayaḥ
translated: In the view of the individual soul - this is the conclusion of the third chapter.

original: iti śrīmadbhagavadgītopaniṣadbhāṣye tṛtīyo 'dhyāyaḥ ////
analyzed: iti śrīmat bhagavadgītā upaniṣad bhāṣye tṛtīyaḥ dhyāyaḥ
translated: Thus ends the third chapter in the Bhagavadgita Upanishad, called the Karmayoga.

original: tṛtīyo 'dhyāyaḥ karmayogaḥ
analyzed: tṛtīyaḥ dhyāyaḥ karmayogaḥ
translated: Chapter 3: Karma-yoga
